comment._content: Aha! The Leaning Tower of Sydney.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
More seriously, that "wonky old lens" might be a clue to the photographer (in <del>1881</del> 1899).  See this photo of Clyde Street (John Degotardi Jnr, in 1900) -

comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales
comment.author: 29454428@N08
comment._content: Could this be the Iron Church being re-erected in Lidcombe Hospital which apparently happened in 1879? www.gordonmoyes.com/2007/10/25/iron-churches/
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryofnsw] I think you are right, it is the re-erection at Lidcombe Hospital as a chapel.  The builders / demolishers would not have left that junk all over Macquarie Street,  and the huts do not match the other photos.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryofnsw] It does seem highly likely this image would be the re-erection of the Iron Church in Lidcombe! trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/18512464

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: WAIT UP! The 1879 dismantling date is WRONG ! More likely to be 1899. A search of Trove for "iron church" produces conflicting reports, but most of the contemporary letters and articles mention it still being used as a Lending Library up to 1899. (It was also a tweed cloth factory for a while before being a library). It is the later reports in the 1930s and 1950s which give the erroneous 1879 date, as in the charming 1953 article posted above by State Records NSW. trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14228725

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: There is a letter to the Editor in the SMH of 27/7/1905 which says the iron church/library was rebuilt at the Old Men's Home at Rookwood. trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14700621 ??

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Ha! I am going nutty from looking at these photos - Lidcombe Hospital is at Rookwood. Also known as the Rookwood Asylum for the Infirm and Destitute. A search of Photo Investigator for "Rookwood" produces several contemporary photos of the place, but not this Iron Church / Chapel. "Chapel Rd" is still marked on Google Maps/Satellite - maps.google.com/maps?hl=en&ll=-33.883501,151.045253&a... NSW Heritage website for Lidcombe Hospital Precinct - www.heritage.nsw.gov.au/07_subnav_04_2.cfm?itemid=5049732

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: It certainly was Rookwood Asylum before it became Lidcombe Hospital. As far as the date goes it looks likely to be post 1893. investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/entity.aspx?path=%5Cagenc... - AG

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] The photo must be after June 1899, when the building was still in Macquarie Street. There is another photo of the chapel at Rookwood - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=204331#
